entry.title: US signals support for nuclear partnership as Westinghouse visits Armenia: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: US signals support for nuclear partnership as Westinghouse visits Armenia: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìçU.S. Ambassador Kristina Kvien hosted executives from nuclear giant Westinghouse, as Washington seeks a major role in Yerevan‚Äôs efforts to build a new atomic power plant. üìç Armenia‚Äôs largest mine took over the domestic airline that runs flights between Yerevan and Kapan, the town nearest to the sprawling Zangezur mining site in southern Armenia. More on Zangezur‚Äôs takeover of NovAir: https://shorturl.at/UEwqc üìç Armenia began filling the newly built Vedi reservoir, which is expected to improve agricultural capacity and sustainable water management. It marks the first time the country has completed a major dam project since independence from the Soviet Union. üìç More on the state of Armenia‚Äôs water resources: https://shorturl.at/vSyWN

media:group.media:title: Armenia commemorates victims of 1915 Genocide
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia commemorated the 110th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide yesterday, remembering the 1.5 million Armenians killed and countless others displaced during mass atrocities committed in the Ottoman Empire starting in 1915. üìç Azerbaijani forces again opened fire toward a village in Armenia‚Äôs southern Syunik region, damaging a residential house. üìç Rethinking Armenia and the diaspora: https://youtu.be/cKBenEQONKU

entry.title: From 1915 to Gaza: The Shape of Denial

media:group.media:title: From 1915 to Gaza: The Shape of Denial
media:group.media:description:
Dr. Taner Ak√ßam, a renowned Turkish historian and the inaugural director of the Armenian Genocide Research Program of the Promise Armenian Institute at UCLA, joins CivilNet to discuss the state of genocide studies. He asserts that the truth of the Armenian Genocide has become so widely accepted in recent years, that even official Turkish policy has softened its denialism.
Ak√ßam is one of the founders of the Genocide and Holocaust Studies Crisis Network, formed this month to address what he says is a deep crisis in the field, as freedom of speech has been severely limited and professors and students face retribution for speaking out on the mass atrocities in places like Gaza. He points to the patterns in the denials made by both Turkey and Israel, and argues that those who fight for justice in the case of the Armenian Genocide should therefore also stand up for Gaza.
0:00- Introduction 0:40- How has the situation of Armenian Genocide recognized changed, especially in Turkey 8:05- The contradiction of authoritarianism in Turkey and the genocide 11:37- What is the Genocide and Holocaust Studies Crisis Network? 15:53- Parallels between Armenian Genocide denial and the Weaponization of Holocaust memory 19:59- Can there be peace and reconciliation of peoples without justice? 23:12- Peace and justice in relation to Nagorno-Karabakh 25:18- Personal reflection on spending Armenian Genocide Day in Yerevan

media:group.media:title: Rethinking Armenia and the diaspora
media:group.media:description:
This week marks the 110th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide. In this week‚Äôs episode of Insights, host Eric Hacopian looks at the legacy of 1915: a powerful yet divided diaspora and a struggling nation-state locked in a dysfunctional relationship. In his discussion of Armenia-Diaspora relations, he explores how ties became so broken, why they matter now more than ever, and what it will take to repair them.

entry.title: Armenia sends new aid package to Syria

media:group.media:title: Armenia sends new aid package to Syria
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia will send $125,000 in additional humanitarian aid to Syria. While the amount is modest, the move is notable given Syria's current leadership under Turkish-backed Islamist groups. üìç Armenia has received an invitation to take part in the 3rd Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) Games, set to be held in Azerbaijan. Yerevan is still undecided whether it will send its athletes. üìç Armenian Parliament Speaker Alen Simonyan said negotiations with Azerbaijan continue and are not stuck in a deadlock.

entry.title: Erdoƒüan‚Äôs power grab and the myth of Turkish democracy

media:group.media:title: Erdoƒüan‚Äôs power grab and the myth of Turkish democracy
media:group.media:description:
In this interview, political scientist Cengiz Aktar unpacks how Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan‚Äôs arrest of Istanbul‚Äôs mayor as part of a long-term strategy to retain power challenges the myth of Turkish democracy. In his discussion of Turkey‚Äôs shifting role in the region, Aktar argues that Ankara is increasingly reliant on Azerbaijan due to economic necessity. In addition, he expresses skepticism about the durability of an Armenia-Azerbaijan normalization deal given Baku's maximalist demands and authoritarian governance.
0:00- What is Erdogan trying to accomplish by arresting Istanbul mayor Ekrem Imamoƒülu 4:03- Myopia over the idea of "Turkish democracy" 7:42- Turkey in Syria: the beginning of the new Ottoman Empire or where dreams go to die? 13:00- Azerbaijani narratives in the Turkish press 18:06- To what extent is the notion of Turkey as a vital defense partner to the West exaggerated? 24:16- Perspective on the normalization agreement between Armenia and Azerbaijan
